scenario_title: Recurrent IP Theft via Internal Lateral Movement and Unauthorized Access Attempts

why.details: The attacker sought to obtain valuable intellectual property for personal financial gain or to support a competitive or geopolitical agenda. By exploiting lingering internal access or mis-configurations, the adversary aimed to collect confidential documents, credentials, and other strategic assets over time.

how.description: Scanned internal network during off-hours to discover exposed endpoints and shared resources.
how.procedure: Attacker uses network scanning or enumeration tools (e.g., nmap, netstat) to identify endpoints, shared folders or servers accessible within the organization’s network during low-monitoring periods.
observable_evidence: Outbound scanning traffic targeting internal subnets at atypical times
Large volume of connection attempts to multiple internal hosts from one account/host
Netstat or similar tool usage logs showing many network connections enumerated
how.impact: Identification of new internal targets enables lateral movement and access to new data assets.

how.description: Identified weakly protected systems and used password reuse or credential stuffing to gain unauthorized access.
how.procedure: Attacker exploits reused credentials or compromised accounts to log into internal systems for which the account is authorized (or nearly so), bypassing typical controls. ([attack.mitre.org T1110.004](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1110.004/?utm_source=chatgpt.com))
observable_evidence: Multiple login attempts with reused credential sets across systems
Successful login using account credentials from unrelated breach list
Login from unusual host or time by a valid account
how.impact: Unauthorized access opens new avenues for data theft and lateral expansion.

how.description: Browsed file servers and document management systems to locate design assets, trade secrets, or financial documents.
how.procedure: Attacker with gained access inspects network file-shares, document repositories and file servers to identify sensitive intellectual-property assets or financial records for exfiltration.
observable_evidence: High volume of directory listing operations on shared drives
Access to folders not normally required by the user’s role
Read operations of large files in design or financial folders
how.impact: Selection of high-value data sets for later exfiltration increases loss potential.

how.description: Compressed and uploaded selected sensitive files to a remote server via encrypted channels.
how.procedure: Attacker packages or compresses sensitive files and transfers them to an external location using encrypted traffic or unusual protocol ports, bypassing standard data-loss prevention controls.
observable_evidence: Outgoing encrypted traffic to external IP/port not matching normal patterns
Outbound file transfer events of large size at odd hours
Detection of compressed archive creation on internal host containing sensitive file names
how.impact: Exfiltration of intellectual property and financial data, causing competitive disadvantage and regulatory exposure.
